item.title: Homelab Diaries: Making a fancy Cookbook
item.description: Yo Chef! I love to cook! And like many people, I've accumulated far too many cookbooks and recipes, which over time becomes highly inefficient when searching for a particular recipe to cook - especially when time is tight during weeknights. I've probably pruned my “go to” list of recipes down multiple times, but it still just doesn't serve me as well as I'd hoped. Initially I began to prototype this project during some free time at work one day using Sphinx, as I already had familiarity working with it for technical documentation.

item.title: Build your own Ground Station with PiAware
Alexa Skills Building: Bad Janet
item.description: Project Motivation Lately, I have been working towards gearing up to sit the AWS Certified Alexa Skills Builder certification. Initially, I received a humorous request to bring Bad Janet to life, and saw the potential to create an Alexa Skill that would quote Bad Janet from The Good Place. From an initial concept, the only “tricky” part of this project is negotiating the speech synthesis, in which you may have to purposely misspell a word only to have Alexa speak the word correctly.

item.title: Private NPM Package Development
item.description: A primer on developing private NPM packages. Packages galore Outlined are the procedures and guidelines for private NPM package development. This guide is inspired by an old dev team I was on, and frankly this has served me time and time again when working on internal NPM packages at other companies. One of the fundamental principles a Web Development team should embrace is the software programming ideals behind the old Unix philosophy - You should strive to build short, clear, modular, reusable, composable, and extensible code whenever possible.

item.title: Homelab Diaries: Docker management with Portainer
Engineering Diaries: Big O Notation
item.description: A look at one of my old engineering notebooks containing notes about the Big O Notation. Understanding Big-O Notation The simplest explanation of Big-O notation is that it serves as a metric for algorithm scalability. If you are currently cringing, or just trying to learn then stick around! You may find the answers you seek… All memes aside, let's break down the opening statement by first establishing an understanding of algorithms first.

item.title: Deploying a React.js app with Github Pages
item.description: With a few hours to kill on a lazy Sunday afternoon… React.js & Github Pages: Will it blend? This is the first Iâ€™ve actually attempted to deploy a React.js project to Github Pages. (Yea, itâ€™s hella easy - and is a great way to showcase your work!) So, letâ€™s build a project!
